qas.question: How far back does Thuringia's industrial sector go back?
What was the result of the economic transition after the German reunification in 1990?

answers.text: the closure of most large-scale factories and companies

qas.question: Where in Thuringia did BMW get it's start in the 1920's?
Where in Thuringia are there fewer industrial companies?

answers.text: the northern and eastern parts of the Land.

qas.question: When did traditional industries like glass and toy making collapse?
When was Thuringia's industrial sector eliminated?

plausible_answers.text: the closure of most large-scale factories and companies

qas.question: What was the result of the economic transition after the German reunification in 1982?
Where in Thuringia did BMW get it's start in the 1960's?

plausible_answers.text: the northern and eastern parts of the Land

qas.question: Where in Thuringia are there no industrial companies?
When did modern industries like glass and robot making collapse?

context: Like most other regions of central and southern Germany, Thuringia has a significant industrial sector reaching back to <a0_0>the <b5_0>mid-19th-century industrialisation<b5_0/><a0_0/>. The economic transition after the German reunification in 1990 led to <a1_0><b6_0>the closure of most large-scale factories and companies<b6_0/><a1_0/>, leaving small and medium-sized ones to dominate the manufacturing sector. Well-known industrial centres are Jena (a world centre for optical instruments with companies like Carl Zeiss, Schott and Jenoptik) and <a2_0><b7_0>Eisenach<b7_0/><a2_0/>, where BMW started its car production in the 1920s and an Opel factory is based today. The most important industrial branches today are engineering and metalworking, vehicle production and food industries. Especially the small and mid-sized towns in central and southwestern Thuringia (e.g. Arnstadt, Schmalkalden and Ohrdruf) are highly industrialised, whereas there are fewer industrial companies in <a3_0><b8_0>the northern and eastern parts of the Land<b8_0/>.<a3_0/> Traditional industries like production of glass, porcelain and toys collapsed during the economic crises <a4_0><b9_0>between 1930 and 1990<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
